Award.AwardTitle: Combinatorial Set Theory, Model Theory of Abstract Elementary Classes, and Borel Combinatorics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores questions in three separate areas of logic and foundations of mathematics. First, the project will study possible behaviors of the mathematical universe using Zermelo-Frenkel set theory as a foundation. The main goal is to understand infinitary combinatorics through the lens of forcing and large cardinals. Second, the project will investigate the connections between set theory and an abstract view of model theory. Many assertions in model theory turn out to have set theoretic content, and the investigator will pursue the question of when there is such a connection and when there is not. Third, the project will explore the relatively recent field of descriptive graph combinatorics and its connections with classical questions in geometry and measure theory.

From infinitary combinatorics, the project will focus on the tree property, which is a compactness principle that abstracts the Konig infinity lemma to higher cardinals. A specific goal of the project is to explore the conjecture that modulo the consistency of large cardinals the least uncountable cardinal is the only cardinal which provably carries a counterexample to the tree property. The project will also pursue other similar questions. From model theory, the investigator will study model theoretic notions connected to the classification theory of abstract elementary classes and their set theoretic content. Particular properties of interest are tameness and locality, categoricity, and Hanf numbers. From descriptive graph combinatorics, the investigator will explore matchings and colorings in definable graphs. This study has already been shown to have interesting connections with questions in geometry, for example Marczewski's question about whether the Banach-Tarski paradox is possible using Baire measurable pieces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major outcomes of the project are in set theory and measurable combinatorics. Since the original PI changed institutions during the award, a substitute PI was appointed for administrative purposes. The work reported here is by the original PI.

The work in set theory was on the tree property, a generalization of Koenig's infinity lemma, and on other compactness principles, meaning principles whose general form is "Given a structure X if all smaller substructures have property P, then X has property P." These principles often cannot be proved or disproved from the usual axioms of set theory, but sometimes they can be shown to be consistent in the sense that there is a model of set theory where they are true. The main technique involved is called forcing and the results often require the existence of large cardinals, which are additional assumptions from a robust hierarchy of axioms that go beyond the basic axioms of set theory.

In joint work with several coauthors, the PI improved the best known partial result towards a conjecture about the tree property from the 1970's which was motivated by work of D. Kurepa in the 1930's. Prior to this, and also supported by the grant, the PI proved a weaker theorem, which became a template for some of this joint work.

In joint works with Yair Hayut and Omer Ben-Neria, the PI significantly reduced the strength of the large cardinal assumption required to obtain the consistency of stationary reflection at the successor of a singular cardinal where the singular cardinal hypothesis fails.

In joint work with Omer Ben-Neria, Moti Gitik and Itay Neeman, the PI isolated the exact large cardinal strength of a non-coding theorem about subsets of a singular cardinal of countable cofinality.

Measurable combinatorics is the study of graph theoretic objects like perfect matchings and vertex colorings in the context of Polish spaces where the graphs and solutions are required to have some measurability property. Results in this area have applications to questions about geometric paradoxes with measurable pieces.

In joint work with Clinton Conley and Andrew Marks, the PI (among other results) completely characterized which sets of congruence relations can be realized by rotations when decomposing the sphere into finitely many Baire measurable sets. This work is motivated by questions on the number of pieces required for the Banach-Tarski paradox.
